content.description: Start sitting on juggy side pulls in the middle of the boulder.  Make a move up and right to a slopey pinch, move right through side pulls and crimps till you can reach the jug at the bottom of the arête and climb up the arête.  Fun moves.
content.location: Middle of the boulder but traverse right to the right arête.

content.description: Start sitting on hold under short arête to the left of the main boulder.  Throw feet on make a move up to the next good hold.  Top out using cool pinch in back. Short.
content.location: Short blocky arête to the left of the main pyramid boulder.

content.description: Sit start for Pyramid Steam in the hollow down and right. A massive, sharp side-pull is a good place to start. This adds a short but fun sequence.
Start directly below the peak on a right-angling edge that's wide but sloping. Make a long move up and left to a similar edge and proceed on diagonal rails to the juggy peak.
content.protection: A few pads to protect an awkward landing.
content.location: The most obvious line to the cap of the pyramid.

content.description: Climb up the slab to gain the underclings under the roof.  Traverse right using the underclings until you can climb over the roof and top out.
content.location: If looking at the pyramid boulder it is above it to the left.  This is roof that is at the end of the larger wall.

content.description: Follow the juggy but sloping arete/crack from a stand start up and right to the topout of Pyramid Steam. Thin, lichen-covered foot holds make this line pretty exciting.
content.location: The far left side of the Pyramid boulder

content.description: Start sitting with a left hand on the arête, right hand on flat edge.  Make one move to the top of the boulder, then move left to a big side pull jug for an easy top out.  Short but fun.
content.location: Small boulder in front of main pyramid boulder.  The right most arête.

content.description: A large triangular boulder that reaches about 20 feet at its distinct, sharp peak. The block is slightly less than vertical, and a right-angling crack separates it from the rock above its left side.   There's a small, angular hollow on the bottom right.
